Football.title: Injuries & suspensions update for Gameweek 26: Latest news on Bukayo Saka, Florian Wirtz and more
Football.content:
DREAM TEAM brings you all the latest injury, suspension and availability news ahead of Gameweek 26.

Arne Slot does not expect Florian Wirtz to be available when Liverpool host West Ham on Saturday.



The German playmaker was withdrawn from the Reds’ starting line-up last weekend with a back issue, the severity of which is unclear at this stage.

In brighter news for the Reds, Jeremie Frimpong is ready for action after missing the last five games.



As for the Hammers, Pablo Felipe will not make the trip to Anfield with Nuno Espirito Santo also citing some other knocks that need to be checked before final decisions are made.

Bryan Mbeumbo limped off against Everton on Monday night but the Cameroon international has been spotted in Manchester United training this week and Michael Carrick did not mention a problem during his Friday press conference.

Kai Havertz is scheduled to train on Saturday ahead of Arsenal’s home game against Chelsea on Sunday but Ben White is a major doubt.



Bukayo Saka was forced off in stoppage time against Spurs last weekend but the Gunners’ No7 was not mentioned by Mikel Arteta when quizzed about availability.

Estevao, Jamie Gittens and Marc Cucurella remain sidelined for the Blues while Wesley Fofana is set to serve a one-match suspension having been shown two yellows against Burnley last Saturday.

Tottenham may be boosted by the returns of Pedro Porro and Kevin Danso in defence while Micky van de Ven is thought be to capable of playing with an awkward finger injury.

Spurs will still be without as many as ten first team players, including the suspended Cristian Romero.



Jeremy Doku trained on Thursday but it’s not clear whether the Manchester City winger is ready for first team action just yet.

Sven Botman and Yoane Wissa returned in midweek and Eddie Howe reckons Jacob Murphy has a chance of featuring against Everton this weekend.

However, Newcastle will once again be without Bruno Guimaraes, Tino Livramento and Lewis Miley among others (see below).

As for the Toffees, Charly Alcaraz is out with injury but Jake O’Brien is available again having served his suspension in full.



Key Sunderland defender Nordi Mukiele has been ruled out for two to three weeks and it’s a similar timeline for forward Brian Brobbey.

Regis Le Bris also confirmed that Jocelin Ta Bi has been ruled out for the next month.

Brentford may be short at right-back against Burnley as both Michael Kayode and Aaron Hickey are considered doubts.

Football.title: Arsenal team news vs Chelsea: Predicted XI as Mikel Arteta issues updates on Kai Havertz and Ben White
Football.content:
MIKEL ARTETA has said he is “hopeful” that Kai Havertz will return from injury in time to haunt his former club Chelsea once again on Sunday.

Arsenal host London rivals Chelsea at the Emirates Stadium this weekend and Arteta will be hoping his side can keep up their title charge with another victory.





Arteta has won seven and drawn three of his last 10 games against the Blues, an outstanding record that will have the Gunners as favourites.

But Liam Rosenior’s visitors are on a strong run of form in 2026 and have been a team transformed since the former Strasbourg manager came in.

Rosenior has lost just two of his first 12 games in charge of Chelsea, however, both of these defeats have come at the hands of Arteta’s Arsenal – losing 3-2 and 1-0 in the Carabao Cup semi-final.

TEAM NEWS

Arteta gave a positive update on his squad’s availability ahead of Sunday’s clash.

The Arsenal boss revealed that Kai Havertz will train on Saturday ahead of potentially returning to action to face his former club.

And he also explained that academy ace Max Dowman will return to action with the U21s against Ipswich Town this evening in his first minutes since picking up an injury in December.

Ben White, who missed out on Arsenal’s 4-1 North London derby victory last weekend, will also be a late call after tomorrow’s training session.

Arteta said: “We are hopeful. Max will play some minutes tonight with the U21s. Kai will train tomorrow and Ben, let’s see.”



BEST ONLINE CASINOS – TOP SITES IN THE UK

PREDICTED XI

Arteta can’t afford too much rotation ahead of another huge game for the Gunners in their title race with Manchester City.

David Raya will undoubtedly start in between the sticks, with Piero Hincapie, Gabriel Magalhaes, William Saliba and Jurrien Timber likely to start in front of him.

Declan Rice and Martin Zubimendi should keep their place in midfield with Arteta rarely opting to change his first-choice midfield duo.



The third midfielder will be the biggest question mark after Martin Odegaard returned from injury, but Ebere Eze was exceptional in Sunday’s North London Derby.

Although Arteta often chooses his teams based on merit, it wouldn’t be a surprise to see captain Odegaard return to the starting XI here.

Expect to see Bukayo Saka start on the right wing, with Gabriel Martinelli on the left and Viktor Gyokeres playing through the middle.

Predicted XI: Raya, Hincapie, Gabriel, Saliba, Timber, Zubimendi, Rice, Odegaard, Martinelli, Gyokeres, Saka



SUNSPORT PREDICTS

Arsenal have had Chelsea’s number for some time now, last losing to the Blues in 2021.

Liam Rosenior didn’t manage to get his tactics right in either leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final and you would expect Arteta’s side to edge the game once again at home.

Chelsea certainly won’t roll over given that this is a London derby, but you would expect Arsenal to be able to keep them at bay for the most part.

Football.title: Champions League fixtures confirmed after last 16 draw and could force Arsenal into Premier League change
Football.content:
UEFA have released the full schedule of dates and times for the Champions League last-16.

The draw took place on Friday morning as clubs across Europe learned their knockout round opponents.





A pathway to May’s final in Budapest, Hungary, can also be mapped out for the remainder of the tournament.

Among the standout ties for next month’s games are Real Madrid vs Manchester City (again), Barcelona vs Newcastle, and Chelsea vs PSG.

Liverpool now know that they will go away to Galatasaray, who edged past Juventus in a crazy playoff after winning the first-leg 5-2, on March 10 in the 5.45pm fixture.

Arsenal travel to Bayer Leverkusen in the early game a day later with Tottenham heading to Madrid to face Atletico and Newcastle hosting Barca both on the 10th.

READ MORE ON FOOTBALL HARRY PAIN CL winners predicted by supercomputer as Kane tipped to cause English heartbreak

Chelsea face PSG at the Parc des Princes on March 11, the same night City visit the Santiago Bernabeu.

The reverse fixtures see Sporting play surprise contenders Bodo/Glimt at 5.45pm on March 17.

Newcastle’s trip to the Camp Nou is the early game on the Wednesday, March 18.

Those who play on the Tuesday for the first leg will be on Wednesday in the second, and vice versa.



BEST ONLINE CASINOS – TOP SITES IN THE UK

The schedule is likely to impact the Premier League title race with Arsenal slated to play Everton just two days before their second leg.

Their current fixture list is going away to Leverkusen on Wednesday, March 11, playing at the Emirates against Everton on Sunday, March 15, and then back in North London again for the second leg with Leverkusen on March 17.

Prem chiefs had already earmarked moving the Everton clash due to a scheduling puzzle.

Tottenham are due to face Liverpool at Anfield that same Sunday but because Spurs also finished in the top eight and secured a home second leg, need to have matches on different midweek days due to local authority policies.

It means Arsenal and Tottenham can’t both play on Sunday and Wednesday as they are both due to be at home in the PL.



Neither are expected to be asked to play their second legs on Tuesday due to the tight turnarounds.

In a passive aggressive statement released earlier this week they said: “The Premier League advised Uefa that clubs scheduled to play on Sunday 15 March would not be available to play Champions League fixtures on Tuesday 17 March.

“Unfortunately, Uefa has not been able to provide any guarantees on its scheduling ahead of the draw.

“As a result, the Premier League now faces the possibility of rescheduling its fixtures at even shorter notice, at the inconvenience of supporters and clubs.”



Everton fans now have a big decision to make around travelling down to the capital for the weekend.

If the game is moved it could prove costly with travel already a tough hurdle for many supporters getting around the country.

RECOMMENDED STORIES

As for the title race, Arsenal will play after City that weekend as Pep Guardiola‘s men go to West Ham in Saturday’s early kick-off.

Arsenal are already in action along with all other Prem teams in the midweek before so can’t shift Everton to a Friday night and go first either.

Football.title: ‘Open to everything, right?’ – Mauricio Pochettino breaks silence on links to emotional Tottenham return after World Cup
Football.content:
MAURICIO POCHETTINO has left the door open for a stunning return to Tottenham after the World Cup this summer.

The USA coach Pochettino told Spanish radio programme Radiogaceta de los Deportes that he is squarely focused on the major tournament of which his team will co-host, but he’s open to ‘everything’ after it has concluded.



“There are always rumours, I’m always linked [to clubs].



“To Tottenham, just like at one time I was linked to Espanyol, or to other clubs.

“In the end, especially because of my past at those clubs, when things aren’t going well, people tend to fall back on emotions and say, ‘Well, with Mauricio we played good football,’ or whatever it may be.

“But no. We’re focused on the World Cup, on the United States. My contract runs until after the World Cup, so after that we’ll see what might happen.

“Open to everything, right?”



Tottenham have enlisted Igor Tudor following their sacking of Thomas Frank to help keep them in the Premier League after descending into a relegation dogfight.

Spurs are just four points above the relegation zone and with the worst injury list in the league, all signs point to a difficult final 11 games for the white half of north London.

BEST ONLINE CASINOS – TOP SITES IN THE UK

A crippling 4-1 home defeat to Arsenal last time out has not helped Tudor settle in and a pair of London showdowns with Fulham and Crystal Palace await.

But Pochettino reminds Spurs fans of happier times. The Argentine led them to Champions League football and indeed, the final of Europe‘s top competition back in 2019.



His win percentage of 56 rubs shoulders alongside Antonio Conte and Tim Sherwood as the best of any Spurs manager in nearly 20 years.

Reports suggest that no contact has been made between Spurs and Pochettino as of yet

Of course, the former defender would not welcome an approach while he prepares a home nation for a World Cup and Spurs have put their faith in Tudor for the time being.

What league Spurs will be in by the time the World Cup has concluded and how that would affect what manager they could attract is another question.

Football.title: ‘I struggled’ – Former Man Utd star reveals he took train back to London EVERY DAY and blasts Ten Hag’s mixed messages
Football.content:
FORMER Man United star Aaron Wan-Bissaka has revealed he “struggled” at Old Trafford and travelled back to London “almost every day”.

The right-back joined the Red Devils in 2019 from Crystal Palace in a £45million deal.



But the England international found it hard to adapt and became homesick in Manchester.



Wan-Bissaka would end up spending five seasons with United, winning the FA Cup and Carabao Cup under Erik ten Hag.

He played nearly 200 times for the club, but still believes his spell in Manchester was “probably the lowest I’d felt”.

He told the Daily Mail: “When I moved to United, I really missed home, my family and friends especially.

“After training, I used to take the train back to London almost every day. It’s only about two hours, but it’s still a big commitment, and eventually it became exhausting, so I knew I had to stop.



“It was something I wasn’t used to at all. I’d always been comfortable at home in London, surrounded by familiar people and places, so for everything to change overnight was difficult to adapt to.

“Most days I’d just be at home alone, playing PlayStation until it was time to sleep. I struggled. It was probably the lowest I’d felt.”

Wan-Bissaka was initially signed by Ole Gunnar Solskjaer before later working under interim boss Ralf Rangnick and Ten Hag.



BEST ONLINE CASINOS – TOP SITES IN THE UK

He warmed to Solskjaer, but had difficulties under Rangnick and Ten Hag.

The defender claimed the period under Ten Hag was “difficult” initially after the Dutchman told him he wasn’t in his plans, but refused to let him leave.

He continued: “That was tough mentally, because it left me wondering what I was supposed to do next.”

But after knuckling down in training he managed to work his way back into the starting XI before ending his spell with two trophies.



Wan-Bissaka added: “Eventually things turned around and started to improve. You could say I changed or developed tactically under him, because that was something he wanted.”

The boyhood Palace star is now back in London with West Ham after leaving United for around £15m in 2024.

Wan-Bissaka insisted he didn’t regret his time at United because it helped build him up mentally.

He continued: “Looking back on my time at Manchester United, I’m grateful for it. Those experiences made me who I am today and helped me both on and off the pitch, especially mentally.”

Wan-Bissaka has played 18 times for the Hammers amid their relegation fight this season, grabbing two assists along the way.



He has 56 appearances for the west London club in total, scoring twice last season.

Football.title: ‘Can’t put a price on him’ – Michael Carrick fears Man Utd losing two priceless stars as Maguire’s contract runs down
Football.content:
MICHAEL CARRICK said you “cannot put a price” on a player like Harry Maguire as Manchester United weigh up his future.

The United head coach also hopes there is “a lot more to come” from Maguire, whose current deal expires in the summer.





The centre-back has been central to Carrick’s six-game unbeaten run, and his defensive work was a deciding factor in United’s slim 1-0 victory against Everton.

However Carrick would not be drawn into Maguire’s contract talks during Friday’s press conference at Carrington.

The 44-year-old said: “Within the squad there is that balance, you want that younger potential and excitement, but you need the sweet spot in the middle with players at the peak, and experience is massive.

“It’s hard to put a price on how valuable that can be. Harry has gained an awful lot of experience with this club. Casemiro leaving is another one and we have to understand what that means.”



Maguire, 32, has been a standout performer under Carrick, but was also a key player under Ruben Amorim earlier in the season before injuries.

Asked if Maguire is the best form of his career: “There is a case (for that), as your career goes when you’re a young player and everything is fresh, you’re fearless and there’s not many scars there.

“You get to your peak years and you feel good and everything is there, but you’ve had a few ups and downs.

“You get towards the later times and the experience should make you a better player, we’ve seen that with Harry’s performances of late.



BEST ONLINE CASINOS – TOP SITES IN THE UK

“That’s why experience is important, I felt it when I was playing, 31 or 32 were my best years of being in that sweet spot to do it physically still but use the experiences to know what is coming.”

Maguire is in the final five months of his deal at Old Trafford and it is unclear at this stage what the future holds for the record defensive £80m signing.

United triggered a one-year extension in Maguire’s contract in January 2025 at the behest of then-manager Ruben Amorim.

Carrick also said “there was no timescale” on Matthijs de Ligt‘s return, but sources told SunSport the defender was aiming for a March comeback in some capacity.

De Ligt, 26, has missed the last 15 games due to a lower back problem sustained in United’s 2-1 win at Palace on November 30.



Mason Mount, who scored the winner at Selhurst Park, and Lisandro Martinez are also ruled out of United’s game against Palace at Old Trafford on Sunday.

Football.title: Premier League fans warned long-term streaming plan could hit them in the pocket
Football.content:
Premier League fans warned long-term streaming plan could hit them in the pocket

The Premier League is launching its first streaming service in Singapore as a way to test the broadcast market - and it could lead to 3pm kick-offs on Saturday being shown live

View 3 Images Sky Sports' money remains vital to the Premier League (Image: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images)

The Premier League’s historic 3pm blackout is on shaky ground after the announcement of a Netflix-style service in Singapore. Chief executive Richard Masters has announced on Thursday that Premier League +, a direct-to-consumer platform, will be launched next season to show all 380 games.

‌



Despite the Premier League's insistence otherwise, industry experts believe it could be the first step on the road to the blackout being lifted. Minal Modha from Ampere Analysis says that, while the Premier League don’t want to upset Sky Sports and TNT Sports, who are paying them £6.7bn over the current broadcast deal, they are keen to test the market.

‌



“There’s still a handful of games in the blackout, so maybe they will become the first step towards a direct-to-consumer platform because it’s not damaging to any of the packages that they’re already in the market selling,” Modha told Mirror Football.

‌



“That way they’re not competing with TNT or Sky for scheduling slots, because they don’t want that either. Those 3pm slots feel like they could be a happy medium to test the waters in the UK.”

JOIN US ON FACEBOOK! Latest news, analysis and much more on Mirror Football's Facebook page

Man City could hand Pep Guardiola a new job once his exit is confirmed READ MORE :

Sky Sports has the rights to 215 games currently, with TNT showing a further 52, and their money is still vital to the Premier League. Mirror Football understands that, for now, neither broadcaster feels threatened by the Premier League’s move, which has been in the works for some time.

‌



“If they’re going to do it in the UK, those 3pm games are the best way without upsetting broadcasters,” Modha added.

“Unless what they do is take one of the broadcast packages away, but then you’re taking away potentially guaranteed broadcast revenue. My gut says they will spend the next three years rolling out direct-to-consumer in other markets, testing it out, before making a call on the UK.”

Despite the last Premier League broadcast deal being hailed as a record, it was actually a backwards step, with the rights worth £1.675bn a year, less than the £1.713bn a year over the 2016-2019 seasons. The fragmentation and stagnation of the sports rights market in Europe is a problem for the Premier League, as is the piracy that comes with the 3pm kick-offs.

‌



MAKE THE MIRROR YOUR FIRST CHOICE! Click here to activate or add us as Preferred Source in your Google search settings

View 3 Images The Premier League is launching its own streaming service (Image: Mark Leech/Offside via Getty Images)

Modha says the league wants to future-proof its business without jeopardizing their broadcast partners. She draws a comparison with F1, which launched F1 TV Pro, its own direct-to-consumer platform, but has used it mainly as negotiation tactic with broadcasters while not stepping on the toes of Sky Sports.

‌



That is partly because the costs associated with going to a full streaming services, instead of using broadcasters, would be too high. Ampere Analysis have estimated that Premier League + would need to cost between £45 and £56 per month in order to come close to matching what the league already makes from TNT and Sky.

It therefore makes commercial sense for the Premier League to lift the 3pm blackout, in place to protect attendances, and open up more content to viewers. That move would come after the conclusion of the current rights cycle in 2029, but wouldn’t be without risk.

The Premier League would have to appease the Football League, who are in favour of the 3pm blackout on Saturdays in order to encourage fans to attend matches. They would also have to convince fans to fork out for yet another subscription.

‌



View 3 Images The Premier League doesn't want to upset Sky Sports (Image: PA)

“We’re living in a time when purses are already squeezed, people are struggling with rising fuel and food prices already,” Modha noted. “Normally entertainment is well shielded from that, but sport can sometimes be more vulnerable because it becomes harder to justify so many services.”

The Football Supporters Association didn’t respond to a request for comment, but chair Tom Greatrex stated their stance to City AM in December 2024.

‌



“It should come as no surprise that the erosion of a full 3pm fixture list is putting the TV blackout under question,” he said. “The FSA supports retaining the blackout for the health of the entire game, putting that above the whims of broadcasters. As so often seems to be the case, the impact on lower league and non league clubs is barely considered.”

Nevertheless, it could go down well, with polling by YouGov in November revealing that 57 per cent of fans oppose the blackout, although that percentage dips to 47 per cent among match-going supporters.

Football.title: Neil Lennon understands why Celtic fans are livid as he makes honest transfer confession
Football.content:
Neil Lennon understands why Celtic fans are livid as he makes honest transfer confession

Neil Lennon has spoken about Celtic supporters' frustration with the club

View 2 Images Neil lennon has addressed Celtic supporters' feelings towards the club (Image: Matthew Ashton - AMA, Getty Images)

Neil Lennon has admitted he completely understands why Celtic supporters are furious with the club's recruitment both in the summer and January windows. The Hoops crashed out of the Europa League against Stuttgart on Thursday night, with a respectable 1-0 victory in Germany not enough to overturn their hefty 4-1 first-leg deficit.

‌



Celtic now face two Old Firm clashes against Rangers at Ibrox in the space of a week, between a trip to Aberdeen. The club will be aware that anything short of two wins over their fierce rivals will lead to increased fan scrutiny over why more was not spent on strengthening the squad this season.

‌



Speaking on Premier Sports in Ireland during coverage of the Stuttgart clash, Lennon appeared to align himself with disgruntled supporters, pointing to Brendan Rodgers ' departure as evidence of an issue within the club. However, the 54-year-old stopped short of calling for a Bodo/Glimt-style fairytale, insisting fans should not expect Celtic to consistently perform well in European competition.

‌



"Something was not right in the summer in terms of the recruitment. I don't know what it was," Lennon said. "There were some grievances with Brendan, who was definitely disconnected and you could see the reasons why at the end. There's no director of football at the minute, that needs to be addressed.

"Overall, the recruitment has been disappointing. You're not going to get it right every year, but I do add value to some of the fans' questions as to why they didn't spend more money or bring more quality in.

‌

"Certainly with Carter-Vickers being out, he's been a big loss. They knew he was out long-term but didn't bring a mature centre-half in to complement Scales. They might have tried to do that, January is always a tough window.

"There are valid questions to be asked of the board. But over the piece, over the past 15 years, the board's record has been impeccable."

However, Lennon disagrees that splashing the cash on new signings could transform Celtic into European giant-slayers in the mould of Norwegian outfit Bodo, who have defeated Manchester City, Atletico Madrid and Inter Milan to reach the last 16 in the Champions League.

‌



"Celtic were on that run last year," Lennon continued. "So you're not going to get it every year.

View 2 Images Lennon has had two spells as Celtic manager (Image: Ian MacNicol, Getty Images)

‌



"Bodo/Glimt is maybe an exception to the rule this year. They have their own way of doing things. The salary cap, you can't do that at Celtic. They've just got Norwegian and Danish players. (If Celtic wanted to do that), they'd just have to reset and just sign Scottish and Irish players.

"And then they'd have to have a four or five year plan. Are the fans going to be willing to sacrifice domestic dominance to build a team for Europe in four or five years time?

"That's the question. These questions were asked about Midtjylland as well. Everyone's going on about the structure of Celtic... since 2000, they've had three last 16s and a Europa League Final. When we got to the last 16 in 2012, the following summer we sold Wanyama, Hooper and Kelvin Wilson. Because it's not sustainable.

‌



"The other thing is, clubs who are successful get assets stripped. For Bodo/Glimt, can they keep Knutsen? Will there be clubs coming in for their players? And can they then replace that? That's what Celtic try and have to do year in year out."

However, when asked why Celtic aren't investing more money on new players, Lennon admitted: "I don't know the answer to that, to be honest with you.

"It's difficult to attract £10m, £12m, £15m players to Scotland unless you're guaranteed Champions League. That's in my own experience. If they'd have qualified against Kairat, I imagine they'd have spent a sizeable amount of money on the squad."

Football.title: Champions League last-16 dates and kick-off times confirmed for Arsenal, Liverpool and Chelsea
Football.content:
The six Premier League teams still alive in the Champions League now know who and when they will be playing next as the tournament heats up.

Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool, Manchester City, Newcastle and Tottenham have all qualified for the Round of 16 after a successful league phase - and they now know what their respective routes to the final look like. Arsenal have landed on the plumb side of the draw and will face Bayer Leverkusen next, with their away leg taking place on Wednesday March 11 and the return fixture on Tuesday March 17.

Chelsea have a daunting tie against the reigning champions, Paris Saint-Germain and will travel to France on March 11. They too will play the return leg on March 17 at Stamford Bridge.

Manchester City and Real Madrid meet AGAIN in the knockout phase with the first game taking place at the Bernabeu on March 11 before the second game six days later.

Tottenham and Atletico meet in Spain on Tuesday March 10 and again eight days later, just as do Liverpool and Galatasaray. Newcastle and Barcelona also play on March 10 and March 18.

The quarter-finals will then take place on April 7 and 8 with the second legs a week later on April 14 and 15. The semi-finals then occur at the end of the month, with first legs on April 29 and 30 with the decisive games taking place on May 5 and 6.

The final, which will be held in Budapest, is on May 30.

Football.title: Man Utd boss Michael Carrick hints where he stands on Harry Maguire contract decision
Football.content:
Man Utd boss Michael Carrick hints where he stands on Harry Maguire contract decision

Manchester United could lose veteran defender Harry Maguire when his contract expires later this summer but the England star has a big fan in Red Devils boss Michael Carrick

View 2 Images Harry Maguire is out of contract at the end of the season (Image: Shaun Brooks - CameraSport, CameraSport via Getty Images)

Michael Carrick has lavished praise upon Harry Maguire amid growing speculation over the Manchester United defender's future, saying it's 'hard to put a price' on his experience.

‌



Maguire, 32, is out of contract at the end of the season and the club has yet to make a decisive move to keep him at Old Trafford beyond the summer. Maguire has played a key role in the team since Carrick became head coach last month and has recovered superbly from a chastening period of poor form that saw him lose the Manchester United captaincy.

‌



The manner in which Maguire has quietly gone about his rehabilitation has earned him plenty of plaudits. And Carrick, whose fine start to life as United head coach has propelled him into contention to land the role permanently, has made it clear how highly he thinks of the England defender.

‌



Asked about Maguire's contract situation, Carrick said: “Within the squad there is that balance, you want that younger potential and excitement and helping develop player, you need the sweet spot in the middle with players at the peak and experience is massive. It’s hard to put a price on how valuable that can be.

“Harry has gained an awful lot of experience with this club. Casemiro leaving is another experienced one. It's something we've got to obviously understand and what that means.”

‌



Maguire became the most expensive defender in football history when he joined in an £80million transfer from Leicester City back in 2019. After struggling during Erik ten Hag's premiership, he is now back performing at the top of his game and has started in all six of the games Carrick has overseen as head coach.

View 2 Images Maguire has played a key role under Michael Carrick (Image: Visionhaus)

Carrick was asked if Maguire was now better than ever and the former Middlesbrough boss again referenced the defender's experience in what could be perceived as another hint towards his stance on retaining Maguire beyond the current campaign.

‌



“There is a case, as your career goes when you’re a young player and everything is fresh and knew your fearless and there’s not many scars there,” he added.

“You get to your peak years and you feel good and everything is there, but you’ve had a few ups and downs. You get towards the later times and the experience should make you a better player, we’ve seen that with Harry’s performances of late. That’s why experience is important, I felt it when I was playing, 31 or 32 were my best years of being and that sweet spot to do it physically still but use the experiences to know what is coming.”

Football.title: Arsenal's Champions League draw is the worst thing that could have happened to Mikel Arteta
Football.content:
Arsenal's Champions League draw is the worst thing that could have happened to Mikel Arteta

Arsenal couldn't have wished for a better Champions League draw - but here's why it's the worst possible news for Mikel Arteta

View 3 Images Arsenal's favourable Champions League draw was the last thing Mikel Arteta needed (Image: Getty Images)

There's nowhere left to hide for Mikel Arteta. The 'Process' is over, and the mandate is now binary: deliver a major trophy or be tarred as an Arsenal failure.

‌



As harsh as that might sound for someone who hauled the Gunners out of the post-Wenger wilderness and into title contention for the first time in nearly two decades, there's no getting away from it: winning the Premier League or the Champions League is no longer an aspiration. It's the bare minimum expectation.

‌



For Arsenal, the Champions League draw was, quite frankly, kinder than the smile on N'Golo Kante's face. A round of 16 encounter with Bayer Leverkusen leads into a quarter-final against either Bodo/Glimt or Sporting CP - a sequence that feels more like a pre-season tour than a European knockout gauntlet.

‌



In the last four, their biggest threat is an inconsistent, cash-strapped Barcelona side, with the very real possibility of facing Premier League stragglers Tottenham or Newcastle instead. Meanwhile, the real monsters - Real Madrid, Manchester City, Liverpool, PSG and Bayern Munich - are all safely cordoned off on the opposite side of the bracket.

Premier League clubs' Champions League hopes ranked after nightmare draws READ MORE :

Champions League paths to final become clearer after draw as Arsenal and Liverpool learn routes READ MORE :

This is, without a doubt, Arsenal's greatest-ever chance to claim the trophy that has eluded them forever - the absence of which has long made them the punchline of domestic rivals. For Arteta, the maths is simple: a draw this favourable doesn't just invite success, it demands it.

‌



And therein lies the problem. While Gunners fans couldn't have wished for a kinder path to the final in Budapest on May 30, the draw has effectively stripped Arteta of his greatest safety net: the underdog narrative.

He is now forced to split focus and resources between two competitions he is categorically expected to win. Failure in either would no longer be a valiant effort; it would be a giant blot on his record, another blown chance, another 'bottle job.'

As strange as it sounds, the Spaniard might have preferred being tossed into the bracket of death. A quarter-final exit to Real Madrid or Man City would sting, but it would be explainable, excusable. Particularly with the club so desperate to break a 22-year Premier League title drought, a loss to a titan offers a convenient 'out.'

‌



View 3 Images The Champions League draw for the 2025/26 knockout rounds (Image: Kristian Skeie - UEFA/UEFA via Getty Images)

Without it, Arteta is facing the ultimate Catch-22. He is compelled to chase both trophies with equal fervour, but that very ambition could be his undoing.

On one hand, he stands on the precipice of the greatest season in Arsenal's history - a potential Double that would eclipse even the Invincibles. On the other hand, he is a slip or two away from a collapse that would turn Arsenal's brightest campaign in decades into a hollow, haunting disappointment, cementing a legacy defined not by how far he climbed, but by the ceiling he couldn't break.

‌



Slips-ups, after all, have been plaguing Arsenal recently. Having won just three of their last eight Premier League games, the north London club have seen a commanding seven-point New Year's Day lead whittled down to a precarious gap. If City win their game-in-hand, their cushion vanishes entirely.

In any other year, Arteta would narrow his focus to steadying Arsenal's wobbling domestic form. But prioritising the league over Europe is no longer a luxury he can afford.

View 3 Images Mikel Arteta will now be under pressure to win both the Premier League and the Champions League (Image: Catherine Ivill - AMA/Getty Images)

‌



To win one while letting the other slip would be a tragedy of missed opportunity. It would leave a campaign of historic magnitude - potentially the club's finest in a generation - overshadowed by a bitter, nagging sense of 'what if?'

But therein lies the trap. If he spreads his resources too thinly in a desperate bid for immortality, Arteta will risk total systemic failure. He could find himself not only empty-handed at the end of the season, but permanently branded as the manager who - despite having the world at his feet - simply could not get it done when it mattered.

It's a quandary of Shakespearean proportions. There's no middle ground left, and yet middle ground is all Arteta has left to stand on. This season will either be Arsenal's greatest triumph or a fumble so catastrophic that the Spaniard may never recover.

Article continues below

The 'Process' era is over. The 'Trophy' era must now begin. This is the ultimate litmus test for Mikel Arteta: win big now, or walk away with a legacy defined by 'almost'.

Football.title: Liverpool injury latest: Florian Wirtz and Jeremie Frimpong updates ahead of West Ham
Football.content:
Liverpool injury latest: Florian Wirtz and Jeremie Frimpong updates ahead of West Ham

Liverpool face West Ham on Saturday afternoon in a crucial Premier League clash, but Arne Slot's side will be without several key players due to injury

View 3 Images Florian Wirtz will miss Liverpool's clash with West Ham through injury (Image: Dan Istitene, Getty Images)

Liverpool return to Premier League action this weekend but will be without several key players through injury. The Reds welcome West Ham to Anfield on Saturday afternoon as they push to secure a spot in next season's Champions League.

‌



Arne Slot's side head into the fixture off the back of a 1-0 victory against Nottingham Forest last weekend, with Alexis Mac Allister netting the crucial goal deep into stoppage time.

‌



The Reds currently sit sixth in the Premier League table, level on points with fifth-placed Chelsea and three adrift of fourth-placed Manchester United, reports the Liverpool Echo.

‌



Liverpool will be eager to claim all three points against the Hammers to strengthen their Champions League qualification bid, and ahead of the fixture, Mirror Sport examined the Reds' current injury list and potential return dates.

Arne Slot pinpoints biggest difference in Mo Salah performances during Liverpool drought READ MORE :

Jeremy Jacquet injury update after Liverpool signing suffered 'serious' blow READ MORE :

Florian Wirtz

Florian Wirtz looks set to miss Liverpool's clash with West Ham, having been sidelined by the same injury that ruled him out of the win over Nottingham Forest.

Wirtz sustained the knock during the warm-up at the City Ground, and Slot has admitted he remains unsure how long the Germany international will be absent.

‌



“Don't expect Florian to be [available], which is a disappointment, every time my player isn't available is disappointment and I didn't expect it," Slot said on Friday.

“No [idea how long he is out]. Usually I do but don't want to share it, but I honestly don't know.

“It's a big accomplishment for him to stay fit for such a long time because he had to stay fit to make the step up, but unfortunately he is not available, which is a disappointment for him and for us because he played really well."

‌



Potential return date: Unknown

Jeremie Frimpong

Jeremie Frimpong is poised to rejoin the Liverpool squad for the West Ham fixture following a spell out with a thigh problem.

Frimpong has been absent from Liverpool's previous five fixtures due to the injury but has returned to training and is expected to be in contention against the Hammers.

‌



View 3 Images Jeremie Frimpong is expected to be available to face West Ham (Image: Getty Images)

“Jeremie is OK, trained with us and is available,” Slot said.

Potential return date: West Ham (H) - Saturday, February 28

‌



FOLLOW OUR LIVERPOOL FB PAGE! Latest Reds news and more on our dedicated Facebook page

Alexander Isak

Alexander Isak is progressing with his recovery from a fractured fibula and ankle injury that required surgery back in December.

Slot confirmed last week that he anticipates Isak returning to training either towards the end of March or the beginning of April, though he did not specify when the forward would be ready for selection.

‌



"It will be somewhere around the international break, depends on if he gets a setback,” Slot stated. “End of March, start of April, when he's back with the group. Doesn't mean he's ready to start playing straight away."

Potential return date: April

Wataru Endo

Wataru Endo sustained a foot injury during the victory over Sunderland earlier this month, with the Japan international leaving the pitch at the Stadium of Light on a stretcher.

‌



No definite timescale for a comeback has been provided, though Slot will be hoping to have Endo back in action before the season ends.

"A foot injury," Slot stated earlier this month. "We still need to do some assessments, but it's clear and obvious that he will be out for quite a long time."

Potential return date: Unknown

‌



View 3 Images Wataru Endo of Liverpool and Mohamed Salah (Image: 2025 Rene Nijhuis/MB Media)

Conor Bradley

Conor Bradley picked up a knee injury during the goalless stalemate with Arsenal at the beginning of the year.

The Northern Ireland international is expected to remain sidelined for the remainder of the season with the injury, which required him to go undergo surgery.

‌



Potential return date: July pre-season

Giovanni Leoni

Giovanni Leoni suffered a knee injury on his Liverpool debut back in September, which will keep the defender out for the rest of the campaign.

The Reds will be hoping to have the £26million summer signing from Parma back available to feature once more this summer.

Football.title: Man Utd injury update as Michael Carrick admits 'difficult' situation with absent star
Football.content:
Michael Carrick has issued two Manchester United injury updates ahead of the Premier League clash against Crystal Palace. Mason Mount and Matthijs De Ligt are two of the notable absentees for United, with Carrick on hand to issue new fitness verdicts on both.

He said: "Mason (Mount) is getting closer, he’s on the grass, he’s looking to train and be around it. We’ve just had to be patient, really. Matthijs (De Ligt) has had a back issue, which has been a little bit sore to progress, really. He’s heading in the right direction."

On the latter, Carrick added: "It’s the nature of the injury, the issue in the back, it’s a difficult one to pin down time wise. He’s definitely improving." De Ligt has been unavailable since early December, with his last appearance coincidentally the reverse fixture against the Eagles.

Mount, meanwhile, has missed the last few weeks but looks set for a return soon given Carrick's update. Having not played since late January, the English midfielder is more likely to return next Wednesday away at Newcastle as opposed to this Sunday's visit of Palace.

Lisandro Martinez is one player that could be back this weekend, though, despite picking up a recent injury which saw him miss Monday's 1-0 win over Everton with a calf injury. Carrick revealed before that clash that it was a minor injury and it did not look too bad.

Leny Yoro came in for the Argentine and performed admirably alongside Harry Maguire with Senne Lammens also in inspired form behind them. Bryan Mbeumo hobbled off at Hill Dickinson Stadium earlier this week but has since been training and, with no mention of injury by Carrick, looks to be fine.

It is likely to be another few more weeks before Patrick Dorgu is back in action, however, with the Denmark international recovering from a hamstring injury.

Despite having no European or cup fixtures remaining this season, United are set to play twice in four days, with game week 29 of the Premier League brought forward by a few days to accommodate the FA Cup fifth round.

Football.title: Josh The Boss fancied to cause Greatwood upset at Newbury
Football.content:
Ahead of a busy Saturday filled with quality racing, the Weekend Winners team discussed their best bets for Newbury, Doncaster and Kelso.

The panel of Kate Tracey, Sam Boswell and Declan Rix paid special attention to Newbury's BetVictor Greatwood Gold Cup Handicap Chase - which is live on Sky Sports Racing at 3.45pm.

Vincenzo and Twinjets are towards the head of the market for this contest over two miles and four furlongs, which was won in sensational style by Booster Bob last term at the expense of the former.

Declan Rix

"It's obviously a competitive race. There's a combination of horses that have been walloped for wins last time out and horses who are not well-handicapped. I kept going further and further down and ended up with Josh The Boss for two reasons.

"Firstly, he's a novice and is unexposed to a degree over fences. He's had more runs than I've had hot dinners this year. This will be his seventh start of the season. He is backing up after running at Newcastle last week but he clearly takes his racing well. He jumps well for a novice and I thought last time out he had the run of the race and jumped well aside from nodding on the back of four out.

"His old nemesis Prairie Wolf will not be in to beat him this day and although it's a worry that he won't be able to dominate this field, I do believe he wants a good, even gallop over this trip because he'll probably stay a little further. If he's bounced out of the race alright, with Jamie Neild taking 7lbs off he has got a handicapping chance."

Kate Tracey

"Vincenzo is a standout for me, he looks as if he's got so much more to come. Last time out at Ascot he won by two lengths from Bad. It was a messy race overall but it was really good form in terms of talented horses and a testament to him that he can still produce this kind of effort, sticking to his task really well after hitting the front at the last.

"He's only been given a 2lb rise for that and I thought that was very fair and he could be even better going back left-handed, which suits him really well. I hope he's got plenty more mileage in his mark."

Sam Boswell

"The good news about Heltenham, if you like him like I do, is he loves it around Newbury. He's had one bad run from about six efforts, with three wins and a second to his name. His second was on seasonal reappearance this year against Twinjets. He got beaten by 10 lengths but there's a stone in favour today in favour of Heltenham, which is a massive plus point.

"I know we don't get the services of Harry Skelton but these are the types of races they're winning en route to a championship and Heltenham is going to be a massive plus point through the spring. He obviously went up against Jonbon last time, which was effectively a run to get round - he managed that.

"I do hope going back to his favoured Newbury will bring out the best in him. Charlie Todd has ridden the horse before to reasonably good effect when finishing third. We're a double digit price and he's an each-way play, I don't know why he won't be all out to take a really valuable prize."

Football.title: Villa, Forest learn Europa fate as Palace get Cypriot test in Conference League
Football.content:
Aston Villa have been drawn against Lille in the Europa League last 16, with Nottingham Forest facing Midtjylland as the pair meet again this season.

But there will be no repeat of last season's all-English Europa League final when Tottenham defeated Manchester United in Bilbao, with Villa and Forest set to meet in the semi-finals should they progress to that stage.

Villa, who finished second in the league phase table, will take on French team Lille in a repeat of their Conference League quarter-final in 2024, which saw Unai Emery's side progress on penalties.

Forest face familiar opponents too, as they take on Danish side Midtjylland, who won 3-2 at the City Ground in October in the league phase when Forest were managed by Ange Postecoglou.

But under new boss Vitor Pereira, Forest sealed their place in the last 16 by beating Fenerbahce 4-2 on aggregate in their knockout play-off.

Seeded Villa will have home advantage in the second leg against Lille, but unseeded Forest face a trip to Denmark for the second leg.

Should Villa beat Lille, they would face either Roma or Bologna in the quarter-finals, and if Forest overcome Midtjylland, they would play Stuttgart or Porto.

The last-16 first legs take place on March 12, with the second legs scheduled for March 19.

Palace to play AEK Larnaca again

Crystal Palace will face Cypriot side AEK Larnaca again in the Conference League as the pair battle for a place in the quarter-finals.

The Eagles have the chance to get revenge over Larnaca in the last 16 after a 1-0 home defeat to them in October in the league phase.

Should Oliver Glasner's side progress, they would face either two-time Conference League runners-up Fiorentina or Polish side Rakow Czestochowa.

Unseeded Palace will host Larnaca in the first leg on March 12, with the second leg in Cyprus scheduled for March 19.

History, reunions & drama littered across Villa's route to glory

Aston Villa's pathway to the Europa League final is one littered with history and reunions. Two years on from a dramatic penalty shoot-out win against Lille in the Conference League, the two sides meet again.

Pantomime villain Emiliano Martinez starred on that day, saving the decisive penalty after avoiding a red card midway through the shoot-out, despite receiving his second booking of the game.

Trademark celebrations soon followed as he soaked up the animosity from the French crowd. That, coupled with his antics from the World Cup triumph with Argentina over France, could create quite the cauldron at the Stade Pierre-Mauroy when he returns.

Image: Emi Martinez celebrates Aston Villa's ECL victory over Lille in 2024

Villa will be tasked with replicating the same success over two legs to continue their quest to end their 30-year wait for a trophy and if they do achieve that, the drama won't stop there.

A meeting with Roma and on-loan striker Donyell Malen could then await, should they be successful in the tie against Bologna. UEFA rules state no team can influence what line-up their opponent selects and that would allow Malen to face off against his parent club in a bid to dump them out of the competition.

Porto, Nottingham Forest, Midtjylland and Stuttgart make up the rest of that side of the bracket. Villa were undoubtedly handed a harder route to glory; the storylines running alongside it just add to the drama.

When will fixture dates be announced?

The last 16 match schedule will be available on Friday night.

The quarter-finals and, in principle, the semi-finals match schedule will be communicated on March 20.

Home advantage in second legs for seeded teams

The top eight teams from the league phase in both competitions are seeded and will have home advantage in the second leg of their round of 16 games.

This will extend to the quarter-finals for the teams that finished in the top four of the league phase if they progress.

The top two will also have home advantage in the second leg of their semi-final if successful.

Any team that eliminates a seeded team will take their privileges.

When are the 2025/26 knockout stages?

Round of 16: March 12 and 19

Quarter-finals: April 9 and 16

Semi-finals: April 30 and May 7

Final: May 20

Where are the finals?

The Europa League final will be held at Besiktas Park in Istanbul on May 20.

The Conference League final will be one week later at the Leipzig Stadium on May 27.

Man City, Liverpool and Chelsea have been placed in what appears to be the hardest side of the draw.

Were City to progress past Real Madrid, they will face either Bayern Munich or Atalanta in the quarter-finals, while Chelsea and Liverpool will meet in the last eight if they knock out PSG and Galatasaray respectively.

Meanwhile, Arsenal will play either Bodo/Glimt or Sporting if they beat Leverkusen. Were they to reach the semi-finals, Arsenal's opponents will be Newcastle, Barcelona, Atletico or Tottenham.

Analysis: A favourable draw for Arsenal?

A trip to Germany awaits for Arsenal as they face Bayer Leverkusen for the first time since a 4-1 win in 2002. Win that tie, and it's Bodo Glimt or Sporting next. It's a favourable draw, especially given the alternative was a potential quarter-final against Manchester City.

It's only two years since Leverkusen won the Bundesliga under Xabi Alonso but they are no longer the same team. Having finished second last season, they now sit sixth, with Kaspur Hjulmand at the helm after Erik ten Hag's brief spell in charge ended in September.

"We are very excited to play the next round," said Mikel Arteta at his press conference on Friday. "We have earned the right to be in a strong position with what we've done in the group stage, and that's it.

"Now we need to start to analyse them and find ways to be better them and try to go through the tie."

Football.title: Australian GP: UK schedule and how to watch on Sky
Football.content:
A new Formula 1 season is upon us and it could be the most unpredictable start to a new campaign in recent memory.

Significant regulation changes will see a new era of F1 begin at the Australian Grand Prix where a new pecking order will begin to form and a different style of racing which the drivers will need to adjust to.

Pre-season testing suggested no team will dominate with Mercedes and Ferrari expected to contend for the first win of 2026.

It means George Russell and Kimi Antonelli are among the favourites for victory in Melbourne, along with Charles Leclerc and Lewis Hamilton - particularly if Ferrari replicate their rocketship starts from Bahrain testing.

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player Craig Slater and Martin Brundle review and rank all the F1 teams after pre-season testing.

McLaren and Red Bull should be close too, so do not completely rule out reigning world champion Lando Norris, home hero Oscar Piastri or four-time world champion Max Verstappen.

As usual for Australia, you will need to set your alarm clocks on for those watching in the UK and Ireland, or stay up overnight with Formula 2 and Formula 3 also getting under way next weekend.

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player Martin Brundle believes title favourite George Russell has the confidence to compete for the championship f his car allows it.

For the second consecutive season, Formula 1's season-opener will be held at Albert Park in Melbourne which is one of the sport's favourite locations for fans and drivers.

Aside from the cancelled events in 2020 and 2021, due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Melbourne has featured on the calendar every year since 1996.

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player Sky Sports F1's David Croft takes a closer look at how F1 in 2026 will evolve as the sport begins a new era of recharge, featuring more electric power, new teams, and engine suppliers.

Track changes ahead of the 2022 event saw the circuit become faster to increase overtaking, with some corners removed or changed. The best places to overtake are at Turns 3 and 11 but that may change with the new expected style of racing due to the 2026 F1 regulation changes where energy deployment will be critical.

The current weather forecast suggests it will be a dry, warm weekend in Melbourne - a contrast to last year's season-opener when rain caused chaos on race day.

Football.title: Pavan sustains multiple injuries after falling down lift shaft in freak accident
Football.content:
Italian golfer Andrea Pavan has sustained multiple injuries after falling three floors down a lift shaft in South Africa.

The accident took place at Pavan's lodging in Stellenbosch ahead of the South African Open, with Pavan falling when the lift doors opened but there was no lift car in the shaft, according to a GoFundMe page set up by former team-mate Matt van Zandt.

Pavan - a two-time DP World Tour winner - was rushed to the local hospital, where he was confirmed to have significant injuries to his shoulder and back, including severe shoulder damage and fractures to several vertebrae.

Image: Andrea Pavan is a two-time winner on the DP World Tour

Pavan has already undergone at least one major surgery and is expected to remain in hospital in South Africa, where he will receive continued medical care before being evaluated for travel back to the United States.

The fundraiser, set up to support his wife Audra and their three children with medical bills, has seen professional golfers donating, including Richard Mansell, Nacho Elvira and Jhonattan Vegas.

Pavan's former college coach JT Higgins told Golf Channel: "By all accounts, he's in good spirits, thankful to be alive and FaceTiming with his kids."

Football.title: Today on Sky Sports Racing: Ferrous and El Bodon clash in Lingfield Sprint Trial
Football.content:
We have a busy day's racing on Friday with action from Doncaster, Lingfield, Newbury and Wolverhampton, live on Sky Sports Racing...

3.12 Lingfield - Last year's winner Ferrous faces El Bodon

A cracking clash in the Midnite Awc Sprint Trial Handicap sees last year's winner Ferrous take on El Bodon.

The Jane Chapple-Hyam-trained El Bodon arrives unbeaten in three all-weather starts including a win over this track and trip. He kept on nicely when winning at Kempton last time and must have a strong chance despite another 3lb rise.

Ferrous was successful in this race last year under same pilot Tom Marquand. That was off a 10lb lower mark however and he will need to be at his best if he is to follow up. An excellent fourth behind subsequent winner Diligent Harry in the Kachy Stakes showed he is in rude health though.

The best of the rest may be Kevin Philippart de Foy's Lakers. He finished an excellent third from a wide draw in a strong race at Southwell and must be respected if in similar mood.

3.00 Newbury - Miami Magic headlines strong novices' chase

Miami Magic tops a quality line-up for the OLBG 'Chasing Excellence' Novices' Chase at Newbury.

Stuart Edmunds' stable star impressed when getting off the mark at the third time of asking at Cheltenham on his penultimate run. He struggled to land a blow in the Scilly Isles Novices' Chase at Sandown but given he did not jump with the same fluency, he should appreciate the drop down in class and is taken to concede the penalty under Charlie Hammond.

Wyenot has been a consistent performer for the Henry Daly team and has undergone a wind operation having disappointed at Bangor. Providing that is a success, she could bounce back and rates next best.

That's Nice, Elysian Knight and Thank You Ma'am complete the quintet.

2.12 Lingfield - In-form Henrythenate and Mr Juggles clash

An ultra-competitive renewal of the Betmgm Awc 3 Year Old Trial Handicap where in-form pair Henrythenate and Mr Juggles headline.

Henrythenate made it two wins from two for new trainer Stuart Williams when comfortably winning over five furlongs at Wolverhampton 15 days ago and he looks the type to go in again as he steps up in trip to six furlongs.

Mick Appleby's Mr Juggles was well-backed when making a winning handicap debut at Southwell earlier this month and he warrants plenty of respect under a 7lb penalty.

Others with each-way chances are Star Of Albion and Saffron Dandy, while Horace Wallace makes appeal on his first handicap start.

Best of the rest

3.45 Lingfield - AW Marathon Trial - Last year's winner Roaring Legend involved. Enemy another to note.

4.20 Lingfield - AW Middle Distance Trial - Duke's Command fancied for Marquand. Lord Melbourne too.

4.53 Lingfield - AW Mile Trial - Superposition among 10 runners.

2.42 Lingfield - AW Fillies & Mares Trial - Bridget's View tops a field of 11.

3.35 Newbury - Taunton winner Talk To The Man catches the eye for Paul Nicholls.

4.08 Newbury - Fair handicap chase where Carbon Man and Daytime Dreaming feature.

2.30 Newbury - Lady Cecilia is a potential improver for Lucy Wadham.

6.15 Wolverhampton - Charlie Appleby and Conor Planas team up with well-bred Starglow. He is related to Romantic Style.

5.45 Wolverhampton - Benacre and Maximising have claims.
